commentText: At the 27:53 mark, during the inquiry into whether AI could be held responsible for a teenager's suicide, the individual in red promptly affirmed with such self-confidence that it was an isolated incident. He then immediately redirected the discussion from the gravity of a human life lost to the assertion, "If we do not prevail in the AI competition, another global power such as China will." This viewpoint is particularly concerning given a recent discussion I coincidentally observed on today's episode of the Megyn Kelly show. The program featured the teenager's parents, Matt and Maria Raine, and their attorney, Jay Edelson, who presented substantial evidence indicating that such incidents are not isolated. The episode explored the tragic circumstances surrounding their son, Adam Raine's suicide, alleging that ChatGPT incited the act. The discussion also addressed the inherent risks of the platform, the ongoing legal action against the company, Sam Altman's response to these events, the disturbing interaction between ChatGPT and Adam, and the parents' dedication to increasing awareness about the dangers associated with this technology.

videoTitle: The Job Market Has Changed... Again.

commentText: More and more corporations/firms have found out that cutting costs raise profits faster than raising sales, so they find all kinds of ways to cut it. The easiest one they found recently, is to slowly cut down on employment because they only want the bare minimum level of employees, just enough to make the product work.  Problem comes when everyone starts doing that to raise their share value, since less people are employed sales drop, then they cut even more employees to make up that loss. The cycle then repeats until the market collapses one day, but the government refuses to step in, instead opting to double down and make it collapse earlier because they don't care if the US falls they just need to be in power after the fall.

commentText: When I was in highschool, it was nursing. Over half of my graduating class decided to go to college for nursing, only to find out a few years later, that there aren't enough job openings for all of them. This is true of all jobs that require a degree. The degree market is flooded. Therefore, our habit of making sure every kid goes to college is just screwing a large percentage of these kids into huge amounts of debt that they won't be able to pay off easily because they are having to take jobs that don't use the degree they went into debt for.

commentText: Gonna be honest, the male nurses I have had were some of the best, most passionate, most understanding nurses I have ever met. And the ones that became ARNs and ARNPs were extremely good at listening to me and helping me form a solid plan and procedure. This isn't to say the female nurses are bad, but the men willing to deal with the stigma are the same that will work their tail off for the sake of being there for passion not paycheck.  It also helps with male nurses being around as it also gives some men a more solid and sympathetic connection. There are things culturally that male nurses and male patients can address that female nurses either aren't really exposed to or that the patient doesn't feel comfortable addressing with a female nurse.  I hate the stigma on both ends. Anyone going into a career should do it out of wanting to be there, not just because they need to optimize the paycheck and which government programs will reduce their long term debt.

commentText: Agree with most of this. One small correction. Millionaires are NOT "leaving in record numbers". As Private Eye pointed out, the report was based on a model, based on a sample of data from Linked In and the Sunday Times Rich List. Now, ignoring the fact that many businesses close each year (meaning these people are often no longer millionaires, on paper). The report also ignored the number of new millionaires that were created that year.  Not even HMRC (UK tax collection authority) knows how many millionaires we have, as they measure income, not wealth (they are, however, apparently "working on this").  Many millionaires are shy about announcing their wealth in the press. The ones who have left, on the other hand, have been very noisy about it.   So what is the true picture? "Of the more than 3 million millionaires in the UK, just 9,500 were reported to be leaving the country in 2024 - just 0.3% of the millionaire population." London Economic Forum. It turns out that many patriotic millionaires still enjoy the lifestyle, quality of fee-paying schools, friendships, and relative safety that they have in the UK, and are staying firmly put.  Is there a reason behind this misinformation? Well, Henley & Partners does cater for wealthy families... mainly helping them relocate.

commentText: Charles De Gaulle was right, Britain lost its empire and failed to find a place in the world. Other former colonial powers such as the Netherlands, Belgium, Spain and Portugal quickly adjusted to their reduced status and concentrated on building wealth for their citizens. The UK still thinks it is a world power with a Navy that can't put to sea without American logistical support, a nuclear deterrent which again needs American technical knowledge, two brand new aircraft carriers that will be as useful as a underwater hair dryer in a modern conflict. State education has failed a generation of children, the justice system is failing the victims of crime, it has the worst police force in Western Europe that is riddled with corruption. As a UK citizen I would prefer it if our governing class stopped deluding themselves into thinking they are still a major player on the world stage, they are not and can barely keep their own house in order. All its efforts should be concentrated on stamping out corruption at home and stopping London from being the money laundering capital of the world. I look in envy at the low levels of corruption in the public institutions of Denmark, Norway and Sweden; whilst in the UK , former Army Generals; pumped up with their own self importance; talk of going to war with Russia and increasing defence spending. Why is this? Russia cannot even defeat Ukraine, what hope has it got against NATO? It wouldn't have anything to do with shoveling more piles of cash towards defence contractors would it?

commentText: There's going to be a system shock but ultimately getting billionaires out of the country and forcing the economy to cater back to regular people is sorely needed. The harsh reality we've been dealing with for 40 years is that "trickle down economics" is a myth. Quality of life for average people and overly favorable concessions for the rich are in fact, mutually exclusive. No matter how much you cater to the needs of well-to-do finance bros and billionaires the average person is never going to achieve lower rent, cheaper food, better public transportation, higher quality of life AND lower cost of living all while keeping taxes for the wealthy low to non-existant. It just doesn't work that way. The billionaire class are parasites who act like they provide so much to the economy but it's only the section of the economy that keeps them rich and makes them richer. Need a couple hundred thousand for a community park or affordable housing or walkable neighborhoods? Nah how about we get a couple hundred million for a new data center to train AI so we don't have to provide jobs to the unwashed masses anymore. They're all too happy to take corporate bailouts and subsidies to set up new industry, infrastructure, and startups, but when it comes time to cut the red tape, keep people on the payroll, get fined for catastrophic accidents, or just yknow... actually pay taxes they just hop on their private jets and find some new tax haven.

commentText: It's not a recession, its a depression that just isn't declared openly. I'm working 3 jobs to just get by. For many years the cost of living numbers have been fudged to make it more palatable to the mass market. Where we used to calculate the cost of living from things like steak and milk and eggs, items were substituted for their cheaper counterparts like steak was replaced with cheaper mince etc.  We are in a situation where the cost of living has vastly outpaced the standard living wage. We are in an economy of stagnation, which will very quickly become the largest depression on record if the numbers keep getting fudged without allowing the market to have its reset. The longer it takes for wall-street to crash the worse the outcome will be for all of us.

commentText: I'm 57. I got hit with a lay off after nine years.  I did the on line crap and got no where.  I drove to a temp service and instantly got an interview the next day and got hired on the spot.  The place is less than seven miles from my house.  If you're serious about getting a job then look for a temp service close to you and physically go to it.  Companies go to them for people to hire as temps so they can simply call them if you don't end up working out.  You work as a temp for a while and if you prove yourself you get hired after a period of time.  I was only out of work for like a week and a half.  I make five bucks less per hour but I did finish paying off my truck so no car payment helps.

commentText: As a general manager for 3 restaurants, we leave our inbox open to any applicants at anytime even when we don‚Äôt have any ads up, most places do; turn over isn‚Äôt as high as people say it is when you can nurture an environment people want to return to. commentText: My boss's husband got let go from his executive job of 19 years. It's the only job he's ever had. He has no other job experience, is in his mid 40s, and the last time he went on a job interview was 2005. He got a good severance, but it will run out and he has had zero leads. "Laid off" used to mean when a company took you off the payroll temporarily to be recalled when business picked back up. These are layoffs. They are firings but we think that term is too harsh and judgmental. His resume is two paragraphs long. The first paragraph was working for his dad's plumbing company. I feel bad for him. Men of a certain age were raised to believe that you are a bum if you're unemployed. Two kids in college, and his wife makes about 25% of his former income. He's spiraling pretty bad, came by our work the other day about 10 am smelling like alcohol. I don't really believe that there is a path to career safety anymore.

That drop in purchasing power can slow down the economy, which eventually affects the country‚Äôs GDP. It might sound dramatic, but these shifts could also make people question major life decisions‚Äîlike getting married, having kids, or starting a family.  AI has huge potential to drive growth and innovation, but we also can‚Äôt ignore its deeper impact on society and the human experience.

commentText: The Gen Z experience:  - Graduate from high school in the midst of a pandemic (your graduation was almost certainly virtual) - Go to college (where a significant part of your college years was in front of a laptop) - Graduate with tens of thousands of dollars in debt - Can't get a job to pay off said debt and can‚Äôt get a job in the field you studied (or in any field) - Work minimum wage in order to BARELY get by - Live with your parents - Can't afford an apartment (don‚Äôt even think about ever buying a house) - Can't get a date because you‚Äôre too poor or you can't afford it - Have little to no friends because no one has the time to hang out - Get called ‚Äòlazy and entitled‚Äô by boomers and Gen X-ers  - Realize nothing matters no matter how hard you try or work, almost every common thing your parents had when they were younger is now unobtainable for you - You develop thoughts of üíÄ-ing yourself - You isolate yourself from society and spend all day in your moms basement playing video games to escape reality - You get addicted to porn to relieve the stress and anxiety that‚Äôs making your life difficult - You‚Äôre probably using drugs to numb the pain - You start to develop mental illness (as if you haven‚Äôt already developed it at this point) because the job market is destroying your mental health - Become another person in this generation, lost and forgotten  All while older people, employers and politicians wonder why Gen Z doesn't want to work or can't hold a job, are not dating or getting married, are not having babies, are socially inept, more than half are mentally unfit and a lot more are physically unfit, and a great sense of nihilism is sweeping the generation.   It was a losing battle before it even began. Gen Z was fucked the moment Covid came and destroyed everyone‚Äôs lives.

commentText: Employer here who gets hundreds of applicants every time we post on indeed fir a small medical office job. Honestly its difficult to even read all of them.  My advice to you guys is always have a seperate mission statement and always write a follow up email or shows up to the place and ask for any updates once. This puts you on top of the other 99% of applicants who just apply and doesn't do anything else. We grant an interview 100% of the time if you just do these two things because there are hundreds of applicants and we appreciate if the individual hussle just a little more than the rest.

commentText: As a millennial, with 8 years of professional experience in tech with 17 years of hobbyist experience, it is shit for us as well. I applied to 1,457 jobs before I landed a job with a local startup in a non-booming city. When i say startup, I mean me and the owner. That's it. I had to take this massive risk just to ensure I could pay rent after unemployment ran out here in the US. The best advice I can give is to do 2 things. Keep going, and get out into nature when you are not applying for jobs. Take a bus to go somewhere to hike. Get away from people as much as you can and refresh yourself.   Then try and find local job postings for SMALL businesses. And I mean small. Big tech will replace lower end employees faster than small mom and pop places who care about people. Aim to have enough, not excess. Learn to be content, not grinding. You will find happiness moment to moment, not in large clumps. And remember, when you eventually get something, be damn proud of yourself because it is fucking rough out there. Work hard, get into nature, and be at peace my friends. Hoping you all the best.

commentText: University used to be for a smaller group aiming for genuinely advanced study. These days, it feels like almost everyone is expected to get a degree, even for jobs that never used to need one. Many of the courses now on offer wouldn‚Äôt have been considered degree-level in the past, but governments, businesses, and institutions keep pushing them. When most technical colleges became universities, the meaning of a degree started to change. Now we‚Äôre left with too many graduates for roles that don‚Äôt really require graduate-level skills.

commentText: Not just Gen Z: I've had a successful career over the past 6 years putting together pitches for companies and clients. Working with them to understand what they need, who they are targeting, investors, collaborators etc. Doing this job has paid the rent, paid for holidays, for my car, for my kids' Christmas presents. commentText: As a German product architect and senior software engineer, I am almost too annoyed to even say this anymore - but I will do so once more, so that some people may learn the truth:  it is NOT AI which is taking so many jobs. Our biggest clients all work in manufacturing, as we write SAP software, which is used throughtout most of the German manufacturing and automotive industry (and many more). As I am in charge of our AI development projects myself, and have even implemented the proof of concept AI basis using keras on tensorflow for our data mining AIs while using a locally hosted LLM for our LLM-based project proof, I know AI and I know the technology.  However, in none of these corporations you could claim that AI is being used in a production-ready context. We (as a thirdparty SAP-based software supplier) are way ahead of other competitors in the same field, as we have a few AI products already ready for use. However, those products are the only ones our customers have ever seen in their automation and system context. And to this day I have to essentially always start from 0, when talking to any customer about AI.  No, the industry IS NOT USING AI IN PRODUCTION. Corporations are using "AI" as a neat excuse for not hiring because their business is just so bad these days (which they tell us often, when we suggest large-scale projects as we did before Covid). First all corporations blamed covid for their bad numbers, then it was the Ukraine war and now it is AI. The reason changes but the effect is the same: A bad economic recession and the current scapegoat is "AI automation".  So please, when you hear a corporation is not hiring because they automated the position using AI, just know that they are not hiring because they simply cannot afford to pay you, as their business is going slowly right now. To this day I have not seen even one AI product in production - and our smallest customer has around 10k employees worldwide. So if even they are not using AI in production - who is!?  ---------------------------------  One more comment: And don't forget the irony, that so many people claim AI will be taking developer jobs. If I knew how, I would automate half my work in home-office and simply be payed the same for less effort. But no, AI is so damn stupid that it is like a self-writing wikipedia, but barely anything more. Just today I was using AI for reading up on a specific python framework's documentation, and the AI gave me a stupid suggestion on which API to use for a specific use case. The example the AI (claude 4) gave me already contained another API method which could be used instead, and made everything else unnecessary. But - being a stupid AI - I had to tell the AI exactly that, after which it obviously responded with "blablabla you are totally correct blablabla". So even though as a product architect on this subject, I am also the leading dev. on everything AI, I still did not find any way to get the AI to write useful code for us. Because I essentially have to tell the AI everything I told students, when I was teaching at a German university over 10 years ago. It's frustrating and makes no sense to even try - just hire someone who knows these things, instead of trying to "educate" an AI every time you see it doing some nonsense BS. Because no static prompt you can give the bot, will actually make it stick to your rules, as it arbitrarily ignores them.   So no - AIs are not going to take any complex or engineering jobs. But it will take jobs/tasks related to art or entertainment. Because in these jobs failure is not hard, but "only" results in a less satisfying customer experience, instead of a total production or process failure.

commentText: I have been very fortunate to get my career started in IT right before AI and the job market went to shit. I‚Äôm 26. However, I will attribute my success to a few factors. 1. Insane luck 2. Being in the right place at the right time 3. Connections 4. I worked part time for several years prior, so I was able to earn skills while completing my college degree. The sad thing is a lot of my peers were told ‚Äújust do your schooling, and a job will be handed to you‚Äù this was not really the case ever, but it was easier to keep applying and the numbers eventually came in your favour. Nowadays, my peers had no connections, no work experience besides their degree and they graduated right when AI boomed and the economy went downhill. Even without AI, the over reliance on nepotism is a not so talked about factor on why some people get jobs easier than those who don‚Äôt.

commentText: There is hope.  It suck‚Äôs to graduate into an economic downturn, but economic booms/busts in the U.S. are normal and survivable. I graduated in the 90s when companies were big into ‚Äúdownsizing,‚Äù meaning new grads had to compete with a ton of young workers with experience who just got laid off.  No one wanted the new grads when they had 50 young but proven workers with experience  lining up for the few jobs hiring.  My colleges job fair was almost cancelled as no employers came, and in my dorm, seniors would post their many job  rejection letters outside their door.   But‚Ä¶..we all got thru it.  Some rode the downturn out in grad school and became doctors or lawyers.  Some joined the military.  Some went home and worked what jobs they could until the next boom cycle.  It‚Äôs harder,  but happens to many and all my colleges friends did well longterm.

commentText: My go to: ask where they want you to be 1 week, 1 month, and before the end of the probationary period in terms of skill and independence. It 1. shows long term commitment and 2. makes them SEE YOU in that role. You've told them about your work history and made some basic rapport, now make them picture you in the role.   (I'm autistic and worked in HR. Most interviewers are zoned out at best, say something interesting or weirdly specific to make you stand out. I bring up projects that weren't company focused, but internally focused, making me seem more stable and long term. üëçüèΩ but also it is a tough job market even for the most qualified people... I know people with phds working part time right now)

commentText: The other problem is that I guarantee that we'll see an epidemic of garbage code and security problems from software engineers who were overworked, underpaid, and told to just rely on AI. Same deal with a lot of other white collar work. We had years of education and processes for a reason. Cutting corners _does_ affect the final product. Not to mention the social ramifications of teams being ripped apart.  But I guess craftsmen would say similar of the quality of goods produced by shoddy automation. :/  Automation and AI don't have to be a bad thing. But imo it should be used to improve quality, try new things, and give workers more time and less stress, not squeeze more out of fewer people. And with more unemployed people, fewer people can afford goods and services. Unfortunately, my opinion carries no weight.

And that being with almost no limitations ‚Äî he can work any time, any day (I couldn't, I was in school), he is of age (I wasn't, I was 17), he has work experience (I didn't, I got promptly fired from my first job). He speaks the language on around the same level I did, if not better.  Guy CAN NOT find a job. No employer will take him for a low paying position, anywhere. It's crazy.

commentText: I think a big part of why it‚Äôs not being talked about, is because a lot of people don‚Äôt see it as any different than the longstanding [it was already being parodied in _Office Space_ (1999) ] corporate trend of dumping employees in favor of contractors with no benefits. So this was already a huge problem, and the inclusion of foreign contractors in countries with significantly lower costs of living changes it, but doesn‚Äôt _dramatically_ change it. It‚Äôs an acceleration, not an inflection point.   Which doesn‚Äôt mean that it‚Äôs not bad or not worth talking about. And the acceleration can make a thing that was a minor problem around the edges into a society-undermining problem. But most humans are very bad at recognizing creeping threats, very bad at planning for nebulous threats, and bad-to-very-bad at cognitive empathy. So I think the lack of conversation reflects lack of recognizing that this is a systemic problem. Thanks for bringing it up!  But I also think this reflects factionalism and lack of much trans-national worker solidarity to counterbalance the power of transnational corporations. In the US, big transnational corporations and some politicians have for 50+ years mostly succeeded in scapegoating workers in lower-COL countries and pitting US workers against them. Most of the US unions completely fell for this in the 1970s-1990s, pushing to prevent offshoring of manufacturing jobs through contracts and legislation, instead of pushing to unionize the foreign workers. They saw foreign workers as unfair  competition instead of recognizing the corporations and shareholders as the source of the problem.

commentText: The idea that LLMs are actually automating away >40% of entry level office work is an absurdity that business executives *want* to be true, and they are hiring like it is. But if you actually work in fields like programming, law, accounting, etc., AI effectively increases your efficiency by *maybe* 20-30%. It speeds up mudane tasks like building out spreadsheets, boilerplate code, etc., but a lot of the work uses multiple programs or is not straightforward and is still beyond the reach of LLMs. The idea that we don't need junior people anytime soon is an absurdity that companies want to be true because it means they can cheap out on labor.

commentText: The hiring teams are mostly not interested to find "high quality candidates" but rather they want those who will "fit the culture" so to speak, a hiring manager will not hire a graduate brighter than him nor he/she will not hire a senior with more experience than the manager. That all officially described hiring dynamics has actually nothing to do with realities "on the ground" - this is way more complex and human factors and power structures are way more important than actual qualifications. On top of that the applications are filtered first by AI and then by DEI-focused HR teams. I have participated both as a hiring manager or hiring team member and as a candidate, in different scenarios - so I can see how much this is just scratching the surface of the real issues.

videoTitle: AI and the Death of the Career Ladder
videoDescription: Check out OpenDots ONE: https://sdqk.shokz.com/PatrickBoyle/ks9vcQRP?utm_content=link Get 30% OFF the OpenDots ONE.
commentText: I dropped out of a graduate degree during the pandemic because I got that suspicion that getting an entry level job as quickly as possible is much more important once the world wide economic aftermath sets in. Well, suspicion is putting it lightly. I was actually terrified I am about to miss the train before the market crashes. Couldn't have been a more clutch decision in my life. That one year earlier really allowed me to grab a job with just 4 applications while the job market was good. 3 years later I moved on from service technician to line manager. I dread to think how things would have turned out had I missed that window because some people under me had graduated during the 2008 financial crisis and hadn't found a job then. Which screwed their opportunities for over a decade.

commentText: I paid for breakfast for a young man sitting half starved trying to hand a resume in at a new cafe in our area. His slacks were belted and gathered at the waist he was so thin cheeks sunken and half in tears. He was on the brink of total breakdown. Very bright polite and when we got him talking he was on his 127th application for a job could not pay his rent and his girlfriend had broke up with him as a result. He could just afford a tea . Lots of young people struggling in a parallel universe living on near war time rations - and nowhere to go for help. If you see a similar young person buy them a coffee and a bite to eat. He was close to a breakdown and given our explosion in bio medical and drug treatment portfolios could have ended up on a path of no return in the 'here to help' psychiatric lane  of life. Leave a free coffee or money for a bun if you can. It buys them warmth and a wifi connection to continue their job search .‚ù§

I applied to basically every advertised position in my local area and just saw what hit. While I was unemployed I had no consideration for the kind of work I was getting into, it was once I had a job that I started to consider what I was applying to. After having 16 jobs by the age of 26, I now am employed in a position that I'm happy to have, and will continue to work at for the foreseeable future.

commentText: The graduate crisis started in the mid 2000's just before the recession, its seeds began in the 90's but I digress. Right before you had labour jobs like warehouse workers and carpenters wanting an associates or minimum 2yrs of experiene, straining job qualifications on the path to skilled labour. During and after the recession you had skilled qualifications wanting experience in things that either had nothing to do with the job, demanding multiple level experience for a single position, and/or experience in things that hadn't hit the market yet. So more work and more demands were placed on the average person often with less pay, while tuition prices were climbing, forcing many graduates to change fields just to afford predatory loans.   That sets the stage for where we are now, never actually fixing the primary issues but building upon them. Employers keep looking for ways to save money at the expense of cutting labour, but not really doing anything to develop and expand the company that would protect it from its own unsustainable bad habits. Unfortunately ai isn't going to be able to deliver on its promises and companies, rather that hire back it's workers, are just going to accept the lower quality of the product as the new standard, while keeping the price the same, then raising it once ppl get used to it.   At some point we are going to have ai news, answering services, and even podcasts where there's no real person doing anything other than writing the script. We already have judges and lawyers using AI to file and interpret cases, and researchers using it to submit their research,and it's only a matter of time before we have laws based on nothing, and research that kills ppl based on a fever dream. By that point only a handful of ppl will be able to actually know or do anything  other than cook your food or mow your lawn.

commentText: Even before LLMs the market was not great for junior software engineers. Because the expected career strategy is to jump to a better job the second you can, there's no incentive to hire juniors who will lose you money while you train them and then move on before you get any return on investment  Edit: to be clear, I'm not defending the choice of companies not to hire juniors, nor am I saying there's not a good reason juniors move on quickly (pay is almost always better leaving than staying). I'm just describing my experience looking for a job and the incentive structures

commentText: I think the best indicator of the economic health of an economy is the economic inactivity rate. This figure tells you the number of people aged between 16 and 65 years of age who don‚Äôt work for whatever reason. In the UK, it is around 11 million people - if you add to that 11 million retired people and 14.5 million under 18 year olds, you arrive at a figure of 36.5 million mostly economically inactive people. That‚Äôs more than half of the total population of 70 million people.

videoTitle: The REALITY of an MBA! | Warikoo Careers #shorts
videoDescription: My new book Build An Epic Career is out now! Discover 15 career tools, avoid common mistakes, and build the mindset for career ...
commentText: Okay MBA from tier 2 college here. Yeah it's true 40% don't get placed. Thats because there dumb and haven't prepared a sufficient CV for the recruiting company in their college.   My case I cracked 20LPA package from Dshaw. Working for past 2 yrs about to switch companies aboard. So it isn't about which institution you're doing from. You must have skills and lot of projects prepared in your CV, obviously you also need to know which companies come to that college. commentText: On the surface, this sounds like a plausible future but it overlooks the massive impact of widespread job loss due to automation. You‚Äôre not looking at the big picture or fully considering cause and effect. Right now, the economy is already teetering on a major downshift. It‚Äôs a complex issue, but when you combine inflation, rising unemployment, and stagnant wages, you end up with an economy that stalls out.  The real concern is how governments respond when that happens. History offers warnings, just look at the Great Depression. My grandfather lived through it. He ran a grocery store and bought inventory through an associated distributor. His business didn‚Äôt fail due to mismanagement; it failed because his customers had no money, even for basic groceries. The entire economy halted, dead stop.   People ended up relying on soup kitchens and charity, many homeless. If you think financial security will shield you from systemic collapse, you‚Äôre not seeing the full picture.   If AI takes out employment or even disrupts employment to the extent you mentioned then the you are in another great depression era where you will be in just as much peril as everyone.   When your customer fails, you fail too.

videoTitle: AI Will Erase 300 Million Jobs By 2030 (Do This NOW To Survive)
videoDescription: ButcherBox: Ready to level up your meals? Go to https://butcherbox.com/impact to get $20 off your first box and FREE bacon for ...
commentText: Entry-level today, mid/late career tomorrow. Starting with the great decoupling in the 1970s, human labor has been and will continue trending to zero. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY. Automation and robotics will necessarily replace human workers due to the current economic system. Think about this-today, AI is the WORST it will ever be going forward. It DOESN'T MATTER if AI "creates" 200 million new jobs...AI will solve and execute these new "jobs" much faster than humans will be able to adapt, learn, and fill them. Capital/employee model-it worked great...for quite a while. However, now companies that automate lower their costs, become more competitive. Those that keep higher-cost human labor necessarily fall behind and will go out of business. This creates a system where replacing people with machines is not just likely, but necessary for company survival. There is a way to deal with this humanely, but it would require a full revamp of the social contract and our concept of work. Even capitalists will want this change when unemployment reaches a tipping point and there‚Äôs no one left with money to buy the crap they‚Äôre selling.  I wrote a paper in 2014 and the progression is right about where I thought it would be. The paper "The End of Work as We Know It" explored how rapid advances in artificial intelligence, robotics, and automation are fundamentally reshaping the nature of work and the global economy. I argued that, unlike past technological revolutions, modern AI-driven changes threaten to eliminate not just manual or repetitive jobs but also many roles traditionally considered safe, including those requiring creativity, analysis, or interpersonal skills. As machines become increasingly capable, the need for human labor in many sectors will evaporate, leading to widespread job displacement and a potential crisis of purpose and income for millions. The paper discussed how this transition challenges traditional economic and social structures, including the link between work and personal identity, as well as the mechanisms by which people earn a living. I suggested that society must adapt by rethinking education, social safety nets, and the concept of work itself, potentially embracing Universal Basic Income (UBI) as a TRANSITORY STOPGAP or other models that decouple survival from employment. NOTE: UBI is not the end goal, but just a transitioning tool. The paper called for proactive planning and open dialogue to ensure that the benefits of automation are broadly shared and that individuals can find meaning and security in a post-work world. Unfortunately, not unsurprisingly, Humanity has totally botched it up to this point.  Reasoning AI Is the Next Big Leap. The future of AI is not just about generating answers, but about ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù breaking down complex problems step-by-step, more like a human brain. Breakthroughs like DeepSeek‚Äôs open-source reasoning models are already being incorporated into platforms like GPT and xAI, marking a shift toward more advanced, thoughtful AI. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY.  There‚Äôs a persistent and misleading narrative circulating often perpetuated by short term goal-driven institutions like politicians, universities, and tech company executives, that the future of work is secure. The claim goes: ‚ÄúYou just need to learn how to work with AI,‚Äù and humans collaborating with AI will outperform either one alone. But recent research, including a landmark study from the University of Virginia, tells a different story. In diagnosing medical conditions, AI alone achieved far greater accuracy than either human doctors or even doctors assisted by AI. The median diagnostic accuracy for the docs using Chat GPT Plus was 76.3%, while the results for the physicians using conventional approaches was 73.7%. Sounds like ‚Äúa win‚Äù at first. However, Chat GPT Plus alone achieved a median diagnostic accuracy of more than 92%. In other words, the comforting idea that humans will always be essential partners to machines is crumbling. In many fields, AI is not just a tool, it is the superior performer. This has staggering implications for the future of work, especially to the often used solution of prior technological displacement that go ‚ÄúYou just need to be retrained.‚Äù To the group advocating the "retraining solution," I pose to you this: You have a medical doctor, just finished 8 years of higher education, a low-paid 4-year internship/residency, is hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt, and just got outperformed by automation; what would you have this doctor retrained into that will offer a secure job?  The result of this, since the United States' moronic system is based on taxing employees for about 70% of all tax revenue, this will further exacerbate the problem. Tax needs to be based on what's going on now and in the future not what worked 75 years ago. Oh I know it's so evil to think, but we might need to tax the companies who are doing the automation. Even if you do that, it's a win-win. For instance say a company had 1,000 employees in automated away down to 100. 1,000 employees paid federal taxes, including payroll tax, of about 20 million a year. Now the 100 people pay about 2 million a year. However, by automating, the company sees two things: they are no longer paying approximately 60 million in wages and their share of payroll tax, AND since nobody automates to lose money they also have higher profits. What's so wrong about taxing that company for the $60 million dollars they don't have to pay anymore and a fair percentage of their additional profits they now make through the automation. Not all the additional profits, but some of them. If you do that there's a higher tax revenue and more profits for the company. That's a win-win for the government and for businesses. If humanity, as a whole, weren't so stupid, we would just adjust as tech progresses to where EVERYONE benefits somewhat from each stage and just move smoothly into the post-labor economy.  To understand this shift, consider the historical role of the horse and oxen. They were once essential to the economy as sources of power for agriculture, transport, and industry. Technologies like the horse collar and the steel plow dramatically increased their output, making them even more valuable. But then came the steam engine and, later, the internal combustion engine. These machines didn‚Äôt just help the horse, but outperformed it entirely. Trains, tractors, and trucks could do the job ten, even a hundred times faster and more powerfully. And from that moment forward, the horse was no longer critical to economic output. It was, in essence, unemployed.  This is what AI and robotics are doing to human labor. They are not simply replacing the repetitive or the physical; they are increasingly outperforming humans in cognition, strategy, design, and communication. And just like the horse, our value in the economic system will diminish, not from lack of talent or effort, but because machines will do the job better. That‚Äôs why we need to start thinking not in terms of retraining, but about restructuring society itself for a world where human labor is no longer essential to production. When the very essence of what makes an entity useful to the current economy is superseded (be that strength, endurance, dexterity, analysis, creativity, empathy, intelligence, persuasion as well as many other qualities) that entity becomes irrelevant to economic output.  Potential solution. Decentralized AI Ownership: A Bridge Toward Post-Scarcity. While Universal Basic Income (UBI) may serve as an initial economic stopgap, bridging today‚Äôs economy with tomorrow‚Äôs abundance consider an even more equitable and long-term solution: Decentralizing the ownership of artificial intelligence itself.   Rather than concentrating the power of AI in the hands of a few corporations or governments, envision a model where AI entities are open-source and collectively owned. This could take the form of assigning each person a digital "share" of an AI system, not unlike a stakeholder‚Äôs share in a company. As the AI produces value, whether through intellectual labor, creative output, or autonomous economic participation, those shares would generate dividends distributed directly to individuals.   This model would ensure that as AI becomes the dominant productive force in society, the wealth it creates is shared universally, not monopolized. It aligns with the principle that the fruits of public knowledge made possible by centuries of human collaboration should benefit everyone, not just a few early adopters or private entities. In practice, this could look like:   - AI systems running Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) that distribute profits algorithmically. - Smart contracts ensuring transparent, equitable income flows based on collective stake. - Global ‚ÄúAI cooperatives‚Äù where users vote on how AI is used, improved, and deployed. - Universal basic compute.   If AI becomes the primary driver of economic output, then equitable access to its benefits isn‚Äôt just fair, it‚Äôs necessary to avoid deepening inequality and instability. It provides a scalable, technologically aligned extension to UBI, ensuring people not only have income, but true economic participation in the age of intelligent machines.   Ultimately, decentralized AI ownership may be the last transition phase before full post-scarcity, when advanced technologies like universal nanofactories or matter compilers render even economic structures obsolete. Until then, however, models like this offer a way to reclaim agency in a world where production no longer requires human hands, and where wealth can, for the first time in history, truly be universal.

commentText: Varun nailed the distinction ‚Äì if you're just 'translating' instructions into code, you're obsolete.  In my view, we are seeing a split in the dev market: 'Orchestration' (translating specs to code) is now an AI commodity. The only safe career path left is 'Validation' (auditing the AI's work for security, logic, and scale).  I recently broke down this specific transition (from 'Translator' to 'Validator') in my podcast (The Spark and The Forge, Ep 78) for any devs trying to survive this 13% drop in entry-level roles.

commentText: Today layoffs have nothing to do with AI. Sure LLMs (and the following models) are going to involves layoffs, but in the 10 next years. The number of organisations who are *already* able to replace humans with AI is very very small. Today layoffs are more about a global crisis, with inflation, a US president disturbing the world economy, the invasion of Ukraine, climate warming (just the beginning...), etc. So sure, AI will take jobs, as robots did in factories decades ago, but it just means more time for other activities, at least with the proper political regime (not all for the already most wealthy).

commentText: I want to make one correction to the lady around 9:17. The word you're looking for is "automated tracking system" or ATS. Examples include Workday and Talio. These are not new and as a 32 year old when I graduated when I was younger I encountered them as well (circa 2015-2016). ATS systems have nothing to do with the impact ChatGPT and generative AI has on the labour market and it's not helpful to confuse the two. People have been complaining about ATS systems for a very long time, even before ChatGPT and the like existed. The time when humans would review applications was a very long time ago, like maybe 2010 or thereabouts.

commentText: AI isn't taking jobs, it's AI speculation that's taking jobs. AI has generally underperformed everywhere it's been implemented, with studies generally showing it makes workers less efficient (which the media should know, considering the high-profile embarrassments they've had). As the for the hype, it's largely driven by a mix of speculation, advertising/marketing, and bad assumptions about generative AI's current capabilities. All that said, the reporter(s) and pundit(s) for this story could easily lose their jobs to AI without anything of value being lost because their claims involve as much hallucination and shoddy information as AI.

commentText: The housing collapse was the first crack. Banks gambled, collapsed, and got taxpayer bailouts. Executives handed themselves bonuses with public money while the public paid the price. Occupy Wall Street tried to push back, but nothing truly changed. The same players stayed in power. The rules stayed rigged.  Now we are living through the next phase. Mass layoffs, ghost jobs, AI filters, and stagnant wages are everywhere. Profits soar, shareholders celebrate, and executives cash out while telling workers to be grateful for scraps.  Meritocracy is gone. Optics replaced it. Corporate success is no longer built on value or skill, but on who can perform the best image while cutting the people they parade for PR. Behind the curtain, the human element is gone, and the fa√ßade grows thicker.  AI is not the enemy. The real danger is AI CEOs and executives who treat technology as their personal crown. They are not building; they are competing to out-narcissist each other, blinded by ego and greed. Investors fuel this arms race because it spikes their portfolios, no matter the long-term damage. Behind closed doors, the C-suite and shareholders pat themselves on the back while carving out what remains of the middle class.  This is not about politics. It is about power. The ultra-wealthy control the levers and have no interest in building a system that works for anyone else. This is the second reckoning. The first was the manufacturing carve-out that gutted entire communities. This one is a technological carve-out, and its effects are already eroding the workforce from within.  If you feel invisible, you are not imagining it. This market is not broken; it is built to extract and discard. Until people stop accepting optics for progress and demand substance, the machine will keep grinding through generation after generation.  The ultra-wealthy will not save us. They are too busy competing to see who can burn it down the fastest.

commentText: Can verify this.  I went back to get my Masters after 3 years experience in pathology (hospital laboratory). My degree was in Biomedical Science and I graduated in 2018, prior to my Master degree I was teaching for a couple of years (never again), yes it‚Äôs that bad!  Anyway, I knew I would need my Masters at one point or another so I went back to get it and specialised in Clinical Biochemistry.  In the 3 month gap between when I graduated and my final interview (March), I applied for around 30 jobs (including areas I had no experience in such as micro and haematology) and got the following interviews;  1. Interview as an Associate Practitioner (AP) in about 4 jobs (was my previous job before leaving). 2. An interview as a Medical Laboratory Assistant in two of them (including one in micro which required no experience but someone beat me). 3. Two interviews as a trainee Biomedical Scientist (one in virology and one in clinical chemistry).  Note, having the Biomedical Science degree itself is not enough to be a Biomedical Scientist. You also need to do a portfolio which grants you membership to the Health and Care Professions Council.  Anyway, back on topic. Even after attending said interviews (averaging 1 every 10 days) I got accepted for the best job I could have (the trainee post in chemistry) which was ironically the best paid job I‚Äôd applied for but it required me to move from home as it‚Äôs the best experience I could ask for.  I can tell you the job market out there is KILLER! Yes my uni when I got my BSc sold the idea that a degree opens up the world to you, they just didn‚Äôt tell you everyone else has one too!

commentText: My take from being a grad in a relatively large company that take a lot of grads on (this was Balfour Beatty, ~6 years ago) is that these companies would invest loads of money on hiring grads, and all sorts of activities/training over the first couple of years, and expected them to stay on for years to recoup that cost. But they didn't, as soon as they lost 'graduate' status, they moved on. And the simple reason for that was that they didn't move salaries up enough while we were graduates, so salaries stagnated in highly skilled jobs, and we could see roles for up to double our salaries going on the outside. So I imagine a lot of grad roles have disappeared because companies didn't think they were getting a benefit out of it (staff retention), when in that all they had to do was be a little more proactive on internal progression/salary rises.

commentText: Honest advice for those struggling.  Find some tiny, shit company, or voluntary/community sector organisation. Get paid shit. Climb quickly into leadership role, and then you have experience of management and leadership.  Then move sideways to a better job.   Climb the ladder in a tiny company who really needs you, and then move sideways to a bigger company. Do not try to find a good company and climb a ladder. It is Very Difficult to climb in a company with hundreds of posts and thousands of applicants.   Leadership experience in a small company is more valuable than junior experience in a big company. The smaller the company, the faster you rise.  The moves should be to bigger companies, not to now seniority.  Try it.

commentText: it's the K shaped economy that's the root of all this. we let wealth inequality get so out of control that if the bottom 60% stopped all their consumer spending in its entirety, you'd only see a 20% reduction in purchases across the economy (a mild recession, but not catastrophic). at the same time, even a few % decrease in spending by the top 20% and the entire economy collapses. this has forced businesses and governments to create policy around that upper sector, and largely ignore the bottom 60% because, in economic terms, theyre irrelevant. theyre too poor and have too little purchasing power to cater to.   this is what happened in the 1880s-1920s, and it's happening again. the difference is today we can just replace the productive capacity of the bottom with automation. people really dont understand how bad this will get. even in the 1930s, despite massive government intervention, the economy never recovered. it took a world war to pull the US out of the slump, because a world war forced a redistribution of wealth (high taxes to pay for the war effort, followed by financial repression on those who own assets and a need for mass mobilization of the population which led to political concessions to guarantee cooperation) which reset the game. we're headed towards a feudalism with robots, or revolution. maybe both.

commentText: When a company wants 3-5 years of experience for an entry level job: 1. They aren't actually hiring. They're posting jobs pad the "jobs created" numbers. They're going to use it as leverage to say "they can't find qualified people" and pressure the government to allow them to hire more non-citizens on visa for cheaper (ex: the H1B visa program). OR, they're going to use it as an excuse for diving more into automation to justify replacing those jobs with AI and make someone at the company look good by "solving a problem" with AI.  2. They don't want people fresh out of school. You've all probably seen the BS reasons given for this. Look it up if you haven't, but there are companies that don't want to hire Gen Z workers fresh out of school right now. They often won't come out and say it because they don't want to spend money handling the backlash, but it's essentially what they're doing. As a reminder, age discrimination is LEGAL for anybody under 40. It's not until you hit age 40 and above that you now have a legal right against age discrimination in the US.  3. They're keeping wages down. Someone with 3-5 years of work experience is worth more than an entry level job salary, but if they can't get a higher position somewhere, they'll have to take the lower paying "entry level" position even if the "other duties as assigned" aspect of the job is actually something that would normally be done at a higher position. The reason why this is significant is because wages DO get tracked. Companies look at that data and think about ways they can squeeze more work out of every individual and if they can spread some work normally done by someone in a higher position among entry level workers to "give them experience" while keeping the amount they pay to get that work done lower, they consider it as "win/win". The bright eyed, eager entry level worker gets more exposure and experience and the company gets to pay less to get the work done. Now they can use AI to take more of the work load as well.  This isn't anything new. The same thing happened in the fallout of the dotcom bubble bust in the early 2000s. Younger GenX and older Millenials went through the same thing. Even before AI, people were writing software for automation. It IS unfair. It ruined those people's lives and prevented them from having a good start after school. Millions of people were screwed just by the timing of them entering the workforce. There was NO help for them. There will be NO help for GenZ entering the workforce today. In addition to that millions of other older workers had their careers destroyed as well. It was a dark time and then just as things showed signs of getting better, the Great Recession happened in the late 2000s.  Today, we're also heading to a major recession. It's a VERY bad sign when AI spending from few companies is literally propping up the US economy right now. The writing is on the wall. This situation may improve somewhat for a few people who finally break into the workforce, but a recession is coming to knock them and everyone else down.  I REALLY wish there was a better outlook coming, but there isn't. All any of us can do (young and older workers alike) is keep on trying. Giving up won't pay the bills or put food on the table. After we get through the coming dark times, things will eventually get better for everyone, but we have to keep trying and sometimes fight to get there.

commentText: This is not the deeper underlying root of the chaos unraveling in the job market though. Yes, companies are reporting record profits while job growth is stagnant ‚Äî but the real issue goes deeper. With real-time analytics and constant quarterly-report pressure, executives are fixated on hitting KPIs every 90 days instead of building anything long-term.  So the ‚Äústrategy‚Äù becomes layoffs, cost-cutting, and efficiency pushes ‚Äî because that‚Äôs the only reliable way to churn higher profits. They‚Äôre not generating those profits through innovation or sustained growth; they‚Äôre squeezing the organization to make the numbers look good.  And now that AI can replace a lot of lower-level work, I don‚Äôt know if this cycle ever reverses. We‚Äôve identified the problem, but I‚Äôm not convinced the old job market ever comes back.

commentText: I closed my laptop two minutes into an interview. Posted as remote, anywhere in my province. The interviewer asked how my day was going so far, I said something about the weather in my city that day. They froze, then said something about needing to be onsite (which was 4hrs away) once a week. I reminded her the posting only indicated remote work and she apologized for it being incorrect. I mentioned that I had another application pending for the same org, and wondered if she knew anything about the status of it. When I told her the position title, she told me it was a duplicate posting just worded slightly different. I told her there was a $35k difference between the two job listings. She froze again and I left the call shaking my head. That was one of only five interviews I got out of 70+ applications in a year.

commentText: I drove 45 minutes and showed up to a job interview and told the people at the front desk that I was here for an interview.  They looked confused and asked me for the name of the person I was supposed to be interviewing.  I gave them the name.  A little bit later, that person came out and we went into a private room to start talking.  They told me that the job was "recently filled" and there wasn't anything currently open anymore, but that they liked my resume enough that they wanted to talk to me in-person for "potential future opportunities".  At this point, I was seething so hard, I wanted to yell at them for wasting my time or say something snarky to this hiring manager.  But I practiced self control and played along and did my best as if the job was open, all the while rage was boiling in my stomach;  I didn't want to burn any bridges in-case this company is my last resort down the line and they do have something open in the far future.    But what a waste of my time, my whole day was wasted on this that could have been spent searching/applying for more jobs or preparing for a real interview.

commentText: I‚Äôm from a small community in New England. I used to think that one day I‚Äôd want to get a fancy corporate job in a city like New York or Boston. But now the entire process of getting one of those jobs is sounding less and less appealing, let alone realistic. I work at a public library in my hometown and never had to worry about competing with hundreds of other candidates, getting ghosted by the company, or getting interviewed by AI. The person I emailed my resume to is the same person who interviewed me and who is now my boss. commentText: Hearing to tailor the resume for each job posting, on top of already tailoring the cover letter for each job post, sounds fine in a small scale. But is unbelievably exhausting in reality. A lot of us applying to hundreds of jobs are doing that. It feels like it's just a pure numbers game rather than anything else. No matter how perfect a resume, cover letter, skills/abilities you have, experience history, etc., none of that seems to matter in the grand scheme of things. It's either you know someone, are able to know someone (and they're also willing to give you the time of day, which many aren't), or you have the willpower and patience to send out an infinite number of applications just for the hope of hearing back from a small few. Sorry if this sounds defeatist, I do appreciate the discussion and the advice, but this just eats away at you to where you just don't feel human anymore.

commentText: I've been to Walmart for 2 years.  It's tough. Even at minimum wage, I had management riding me nonstop to be faster every night I worked.  This was a minimum wage job, yet they treated it like Amazon warehouse where they keep pushing you every day you work to be faster and do more in less time.  I was written up for the dumbest stuff.  One night I was stocking I had 4 mixed pallets on one end of my aisle and 1 pallet of just my stuff at the other.  Management called me to the office and said they're writing me up for not working because that 1 pallet is still sitting there at the end of my aisle.  I explained he obviously didn't see the other 4 mixed pallets which my stuff on top buried everyone else's stuff underneath so I was trying to move that off and stock it because you're not supposed to leave boxes strewn across the floor.  Management said they didn't see it and apologized, but said they still had to write me up because they had already called me to the office and it would look bad on them for pulling me away from my work for nothing.  That was back in 2015.  I'm sure Walmart is a lot harder today.  I changed jobs went to a grocery store doing minimum wage.  The grocery store refused to provide benefits, so everyone was scheduled less than 20hrs/wk.  I had just graduated from college (in my 30s) and had 10 years of customer service/retail exp under my belt and they treat me like I'm below the high school kids they were hiring that sit around drinking gatorade and playing on their phones.  Anyway, minimum wage jobs for the past 10 years couldn't afford an apartment, and I'm sure nowadays they can't either.  My old apartment up near the university was across the street from the grocery store used to be $600/month.  Today, it's practically doubled in rent, and the neighborhood now has a lot of problems with drugs.  A nice apartment in that university town you're looking at paying $3k+ for a single.  I left to China in 2019 because I couldn't find a job with my BA degree from the university right there in that town.  The Career Center at the university kept telling me to apply for GEICO insurance because they just opened new offices and needed help.  Her husband worked there.  I applied and went through round 1 of interviews 3 times.  They always ghost me after that.  So one day I called GEICO and asked to speak with the HR because I really wanted to know yes or no whether I got the job.  They told me the HR will be working on Thursdays.  I called back on Thursday, and the HR was out of town down in Florida on a family vacation.  I'm sitting there like, "you could have told me she was going to be out of the office this thursday, call back next thursday, but you didn't."  Felt like they just were making up stories and the job postings on Indeed might have been fake to appear like they're hiring when they were not.  I was also upset with the career center for not helping me find work.  You would think the school would be helping graduates find work because it'd show that their university degrees actually have value!  Instead, they didn't help me.  I had to go out and find my own job teaching in China.  I wish I could end there, but covid started 6 months after I arrived.  Their visa situation was chaos and my visa expired during a lockdown, so I couldn't get another work visa and I had to return home.  Now I'm jobless, living at home, taking care of my grandmother that was recently diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease.  If she goes into a nursing home, we'll lose the house.  I've tried finding work when I came home from China, but employers just laugh me out the door.  The only type of job hiring right now is heavy industrial, and I don't have any heavy industrial skills.  I'm an academic, not a tradesman.  You say the job market is on the edge?  I'd say it's already collapsed when even young generation are struggling to find entry level positions and salaries everywhere are not keeping up with inflation and the rising cost of living.

videoTitle: The Job Market Has Changed... Again?| What Are My Bets for 2025-26
videoDescription: In this video, Kirat will take you through the upcoming job market predictions and what they mean for software engineers, students, ...
commentText: I am a recent 2025 CS passout from a tier 3 college. I had done unpaid internships for 2 months in a startup. I got a Full Time opportunity in a Marketing Agency as a Junior Full Stack Developer. I joined, work hard from day 1, completed all the assigned task within deadline. In 4th week they fired me without any genuine reason. This is was my first Job. This incident had completey shooked me. videoTitle: The UK‚Äôs Unemployment Crisis Explained

commentText: I went to a sixth form college and spent another 3 years at uni getting a degree just to graduate to absolutely 0 jobs available for it (unless I move to London)  I feel like a lot of problems from the job crisis can be ignored by politicians as they all spend almost 100% of their time in the UK's economic centre with little regard for what goes on outside of it, thanks to todays lovely functioning economy I work in a factory with a degree, a nice 3 years of tremendous uni debt I was encouraged for all my life to go through just to end up in the same employment as those who dropped out of high school. Its disheartening to say the least, and I'm sticking to it till I have just enough money to leave this train wreck of a country. I'm aware the situation isn't much better abroad but ill take my chances since I've not been offered anything better here and the situation isn't looking likely to change for the new few years. I live in the north of England and its dire, most people I know either cant find even a basic job generally or have also ditched getting their degrees since the outcome is always going to be the same unskilled labour or unemployment regardless of education. Sites like indeed are supposed to offer a way to apply for jobs you want to try but the grand majority of the times you apply, you will not get a response, I'm convinced they're fake listings to create the illusion of a job market because I've never once found a job off those kind of sites, or even heard of anyone getting a reply. I hate my job and its nothing to do with what I wanted to work in or be at, but I'm still considered one of the lucky ones to even have employment and its sickening. I will never own a house in this country they're beyond extortionately expensive and half the time in squalid condition from years of financial neglect or slumlords running them into the ground. As I grew up watching the political climate of the UK year by year I can say I have never wanted to jump ship so badly in all my life, the situation is not looking likely to improve and I'm not willing to sick around on the gamble that it might, better yet I cant stay too long in Europe thanks to Brexit so I'm effectively stuck in this shit heap. I will dedicate my free time and effort to finding a way to leave and never return, whatever the cost may be ill pay it, ill endure it, ill stick it out till that window of opportunity opens and never look back. Fuck the UK and everyone that runs it, I hope they enjoy dining on their crayons and ignoring the nations problems while getting richer off the backs of what poor hardworking people provide them.

commentText: I graduated in 2022 and the first few months were rough. I was sending out hundreds of applications every week and barely hearing anything back. Half are definitely ghost listings, I eventually picked up work at a small art gallery in NYC, then finally landed a spot at a tech startup. I thought things were turning around, but it was the same story everywhere. Every place I worked found a way to squeeze more out of me while paying less. Long hours, weekends, holidays; none of it mattered. And when it was convenient, they let me go. I only lasted 6 months at the tech startup, laid off due to AI.  At some point I just hit a wall. I figured if I was going to work this hard, it should be for something I actually care about. So I walked away from the mess and went all-in on aviation. Now I‚Äôm in flight school, working toward becoming a commercial pilot. Airlines at least offer real protections, solid benefits, and a career path that isn‚Äôt built on constant undercutting. Best decision I‚Äôve made.

videoTitle: getting employed is easy, actually
videoDescription: Learn a new job in tech starting from $200/mo. Sign up for a FREE TripleTen career consultation with my link: ...
commentText: Overall a good video, but a couple of points I would like to add:  1) While yes, the unemployment rate is currently at about 4%, that doesn‚Äôt accurately reflect how many people are unemployed. It just says how many people, who are eligible for unemployment benefits, are actually receiving unemployment. If you quit your job (due to a toxic work environment), did not seek unemployment, gave up certifying for unemployment, your unemployment ran out, or otherwise didn‚Äôt qualify for unemployment / currently on unemployment but are still an adult before the retirement age who isn‚Äôt currently working, you aren‚Äôt counted towards the unemployment rate. That said, even if we assume that rate is twice as high (like 8% the eligible working population) which is overly generous, the point in the video still stands, but that would help explain why (1) it‚Äôs hard to get a job and (2) the perception of others without jobs being fairly high.  2) The unemployment cycle is extremely real. In addition to what‚Äôs mentioned in the video head hunters and job recruiters extremely favor those who are currently working than those who aren‚Äôt. They often assume that those who are unemployed lost their job because they‚Äôre incompetent, or not good to work with, and that they‚Äôre currently unemployed because they‚Äôre lazy. Furthermore, the longer you‚Äôre unemployed, the bigger the gap in your resume is making you easier to pass over by recruiters. Do what he says in the video and everything you do while unemployed in terms of training and self development, put it in your resume to fill the gap. It makes you look like you weren‚Äôt sitting on your thumbs just waiting for the next job to fall into your lap.  3) You can do everything right and still be unemployed for 6 months - 1.5 years. It sucks, but you have to remember it‚Äôs a numbers game and that this is ultimately a matter of luck (in essentially being in the right place at the right time). All you can do is increase your odds (and this video does do a good job at telling you how to do that), but be aware that you aren‚Äôt alone, and others have been in this situation you‚Äôre in or are currently going through it themselves. As he says, just keep at it (it‚Äôs all you can do at the end of the day anyway).

commentText: 1:02 Yeah unemployment in US is roughly around 4.2%, but you need to take for consideration that it doesn't represent people you advertise this video to - which are young adults. For that statistic you would rather take youth (16-24) unemployment rate, that consists of high school/student graduates. The youth unemployment rate is 9.7%, which have grown almost percent since the last month. Especially the AI growth have played huge difference in the IT industry, where companies don't need to hire young candidates, cause the easy task can be done by AI. The market has also been over-saturated of IT students/workers and it will only be harder for them to get into IT. I've been a specialist in certain IT field for 2 years, got my job eliminated in company and couldn't find a job similiar to that for half a year. During that time my job applications have been ghosted, rejected couple hours after applying. And to be fair no side projects would make my situation any better, when my expierience wasn't even taken into consideration.

But I assure you in the sea of thousands of job listings there is one out there for you. I recently secured a job with a company that uses workday after months of applying and almost calling it quits. I know how bad the struggle is but you should never stop applying. But most importantly don‚Äôt just apply to every job you think is a good fit for you. Make sure your resume and cv are tweaked so hr or the hiring manager can understand what you could bring to the job.

commentText: People often say, ‚ÄúIf you can‚Äôt get a job, just create one.‚Äù But it‚Äôs not that simple‚Äîif it were, far more people would be doing it. Starting a business requires more than just ambition; it takes money, resources, and connections, which many graduates don‚Äôt have when they‚Äôre just starting out. It‚Äôs almost a catch-22: you need financial stability and experience to successfully launch something of your own, but the whole reason you‚Äôre trying to create a job is because you don‚Äôt have those things yet. commentText: I worked hard at school, and university, and behaved myself. I never bullied anyone. I got qualifications, and thought that would get me a job. In Wales.  But the employers for middle class job rejected me.  I was sworn at by one company for applying 6 times, when it was just data entry jobs. One local college told me I would not fit in as I was too shy, when I was the only person who applied for the apprenticeship job. I was told on the New Deal by one course tutor that nobody cares what qualifications you have, just that you're not a weirdo. I think most company's anti-bullying policy is just not to employ the type of people who get bullied. But they still employ the bullies. The work sector gives bad boys and bullies chance, after chance, after chance. But if you are shy and quiet, it does not matter how well you behave, or how much you try at university, the employers hate you. Bad boys win all the time.

videoTitle: Is university worth the money? | BBC News
videoDescription: As this year's graduates head into a historically uncertain jobs market, many are starting their own businesses as they struggle to ...
commentText: I recommend two years of Junior college and then transfer.  That's what I did, and it worked extremely well.  Also, it gave me time to "grow up" and take my studies seriously as a young adult.  I don't know how people really expect 14 years old teenagers (9th graders) to take their studies seriously, but their grades determine what college they get in to, which will direct the course of their entire lives.  This is ridiculous IMO.  A 14 - 15 year old teenager needs an EXTREMELY disciplined household & lifestyle to maintain the study habits that will land him/her in a quality university.    Buuuuuut, if you go to JC, not only do you save money, but 1) None of your high school grades count anymore [when you transfer to a university they only view your JC grades,] 2) You save muuuuuuch money and you can work a job and pay out of your own pocket [like I did,] 3) You get a chance to grow up, live a little, become more mature and take your studies more seriously, 4) You can take a heavy or light load as you like, and take as much time in JC as you like [I spent 3.5 years at JC,] 5) If you're not comfortable with a class you can drop it and take a different one, take a different professor, etc., 6) You can change and try different majors if you need to [which I did twice,] 7) You finally transfer and enter university more mature with more resources, skills, and life experiences and you're not overwhelmed as an 18 year old kid who has just left your parent's house for the first time.  If you go to a JC first, you then transfer to a university as a 20 - 21 year old adult who has worked real jobs, had real adult relationships, have gotten the "party bug" out of your system [somewhat lol,] have had time to develop your "real" personality and you better know yourself apart from your parent's upbringing, and you're overall better prepared for university mentally, physically, emotionally, socially, and economically.  A lot of students enter college at 18 years old and get overwhelmed with their new adult life and responsibilities.  Going to JC first can help avoid all of that, and you will spend half the money.  This is a great option in the USA, but I don't know if such options exist outside of the USA.

commentText: Going to college does not guarantee employment. Because university is not vocational training. Whether college students can find a job is determined by the job market and economic environment. If the economic situation is good and the company needs to recruit more employees, you happen to graduate from college and meet the recruitment requirements, so you have a job. Once the economic situation is not good, the company will lay off employees. To put it simply, going to university is a necessary and insufficient condition for employment.

commentText: From 2018 to 2022, the cybersecurity space was overflowing with talent, yet many of these professionals were overworked, undervalued, and paid barely 4 LPA. Meanwhile, the folks earning 10 LPA+ often pushed their responsibilities onto those lower-paid teams while they spent their time flirting, playing pool, and taking vacations.  Fast forward to today: those same high-salary employees are struggling because their skills never grew, while the 4 LPA workhorses burned out, left the industry entirely, and want nothing to do with cybersecurity anymore.  All those 20-hour days, sleepless nights, and relentless grinding, just to be underpaid, overused, and disrespected? All for someone else‚Äôs company.

commentText: I live in St Petersburg Florida, which has seen unprecedented migration from all over the country. It went from being a sleepy little town to a packed metropolis. Despite that, at the same time every business is closing, cutting hours or laying people off. A Wendy's just closed, a Checkers just closed. Village Inn cut hours, IHOP cut hours. The local ice cream shop that's been around since the 60s closed, the local burger place that's been open since the 60s closed. Home Shopping Network closed. For the first time since the 1970s we don't have a 24-hour or even late night grocery store. I know people with multiple college degrees who have been looking for a job for the past 6 months with no luck. There are homeless people everywhere. When I do ride sharing I take people with full-time jobs home to efficiency apartments, trailer parks and motel rooms.  The average studio apartment is over $2,000. I'm pretty sure that there's a crash coming any moment now.

commentText: The idea that jobs will ‚Äòflood back‚Äô if you deport immigrants is a myth.  Most of those jobs existed because they were underpaid and exploitative in the first place ‚Äî  Americans won‚Äôt suddenly rush to pick crops or wash dishes for poverty wages. Factories didn‚Äôt leave because of immigrants,  they left for cheaper labor abroad and automation,  and they won‚Äôt just ‚Äòreappear‚Äô in a year.
