commentText: The economy is suffering due to poor fundamentals.  These include the overall phenomenon called "structural unemployment."  Some economists have predicted this for decades because of its Malthusian essence.  Too many people, not enough jobs.  It will never return to what was.  It's not part of normal economic cycles that the experts are so fond of citing. It's exacerbated by AI and robotics.  Unless the government was proactive in planning to make society more socialistic, and improving conditions for citizens, then it's a down hill slide towards a plutocracy. Unfortunately that's the widening chasm between the rich and the poor, leaving the mid-class in tatters trying to maintain their standard of living in a country where the average person is involved in a non-consensual relationship with an economy hell bent on fleecing the shit out of people.  The automobile is the biggest fraud ever perpetrated on a populace. Just add up all the costs inherent in the operation of your car and hang up and drive.  The fender bender industry wants you on your phone, with headlights unique to each model and absurd prices for injection molded parts with insane margins. Back to the acyclic economic milieu in which we exist.  The end of the petroleum age means that we are seeing prices rise based on a truer calculation of embedded costs.   The slow death of urban core retail means that commercial real estate is getting shitty, and that sector has anchored funds and such for years.   Bankers are slow to adjust. Every company is squeezing everything for revenue, meaning the firings and the terrible job market are the tip of the iceberg. The guy who got voted in isn't doing anything to help you folks that believed the rhetoric.  He just wants to aggrandize himself and his cronies by reviving the polluting of our country while bad mouthing renewable energy because of its effect on the "landscape."   Since when has he given a shit about the natural world? Has he visited an open pit mine recently.  He has doubled his net worth over the last 6-18 months, while most US citizens are suffering.   Make no mistake: He doesn't give a shit about any of us, unless you're part of the war machine dominated by the Big 5 and go to Davos or Tetons.   Over Easter he dismissed us all and said "just enjoy your life" in a display of such callous indifference the average person's plight as to be obscene. He has begun to take away the basic right to free speech and his attacks on people smarter than he is who criticize what is happening is truly frightening.  We should all be very concerned and petition our generally greedy representatives who are often focused on their own inside information making their assisted stock market picks way easier. Stop attacking people who you might call liberal and understand that it will require all of us to find accord and quorum to achieve any progress.   Infighting and factionalism will be our downfall.

commentText: The first main problem is that businesses are being dissuaded from investing in creating jobs due to the employers' NI rise (effectively a tax on your job), the Employment Rights Bill adding further costs, and the lack of a clear economic strategy from the Treasury.   The second problem is that at the low end of the income scale, you're often far better off choosing benefits as a career than a minimum wage job due to the differences in support schemes and taxes. Hence the massive increase in claims for nebulous conditions like "anxiety" or "ADHD", especially among young people.   The solution is to look to Denmark, where employment rights are surprisingly limited and make it easy to hire and fire employees. However, they can do this because fired workers get quite a generous amount of support from the welfare system, but that support is limited in time and scope. You're strongly pushed into training courses or looking for a job, and it'll get yanked after a couple of years. That means there's a good safety net that is only temporary, and businesses are more willing to hire people, safe in the knowledge that they can be binned off if they don't work out.

commentText: My company closed down because of Covid. I worked in the travel industry. From experience, I know that job sites are a complete waste of time. So, I started doing part time jobs - in vaccination centres and on certain days, I did part time jobs at various companies - including dish washing, usher, etc. In the vaccination centre during Covid, my colleagues were air stewardess, pilots, etc. These people were pragmatic. In a crisis, you need money. You cannot wait indefinitely at home. Find any part time job and even if you bring home $1,000, it is still better than zero. Till today, I am still a part time. I am a 63 year old Singaporean.

commentText: I resonated so much with Uzen here. I was working in a medical device MNC once and I was at my peak, where I was just promoted and given a higher salary. Just two months later, I was given a one month notice and was amongst the hundreds that were laid off.   Left jobless for 6 months, I had to work whatever I could to earn enough to pay bills and mentally preparing myself for a depleted CPF which may affect my mortgage.   I eventually landed a job but the salary package was very very low as compared to my previous employment, so I knew I couldn‚Äôt stay there for too long. I took that opportunity during the low-salary employment to apply for the next best role - with hopes it will be enough to support an ever rising cost of living.   At this rate, I worry more about our future generations to come

commentText: There was a time I spammed job applications and secured a job unrelated to my bachelors education and work experience. What helped was transferrable skills I had shown in my resume highlighting myself as a team player, leadership, service operations experience.   Applied close to 500 jobs, went for 1-2 interviews a week for around 4 months. Only after around 400 applications I decided to be more open to jobs out of my scope of experience and industry. Secured one that actually value added to my resume and helped me get headhunted one year later due to my transferrable skills and existing skills. Headhunted for another industry unrelated to previous job.   Each job change was unrelated to my previous.

videoTitle: 30 And Jobless: Why's Unemployment Rising For Those In Their 30s? | Talking Point | Forum
videoDescription: We often hear about unemployment woes of fresh grads‚Ä¶even older olders in their 50s‚Ä¶ but what about those who are in the ...
commentText: We keep talking like unemployment should be the only stat relevant... what about quality jobs? what about the distribution of wealth?  i'd argue that the latter is the main problem. This fully capitalist society, both on a corporate and country level, and the latter is especially so for singapore, has priced out people who actually need these resources.   People in their 30s cannot afford to be stuck in a situation where they have 30 year, 1 million dollar mortgages to pay off when the median salary is only 5.5k.   You are forcing people into desperate measures.  on the other hand, the government is offering tax breaks and subsidies to companies that end up not sharing the bottom line.  It is a pretty simple problem with a pretty simple solution: Tax those with plenty and tax less to those without.   If you are not going to tax, force the company to pay out the tax savings in salaries. companies will find a way to pay people properly and hire more. stress levels will decrease. productivity on a corporate level, either remains the same, or increases because all teams have more manpower. the only people that suffer are upper management and shareholders, whom are already making enough.  CEOs used to make 20 times more than a production worker. Now a CEO of a bank can make 300x more than a median salary worker. how do these upper management get a raise? by laying off people they dont like and keeping some of it as their profit. People at the top with super jobs just blame their surbordinates for the lack of production and fire them. dont see much job risk for them, and they only need to stay in those positions for 2 years to make what a normal person will make in a lifetime. When we question why they need to make so much, they justify by saying that they worked really hard with more responsibilities, but others havent. truth is, most people equally hard, but a selected, already rich few clog up the super jobs and dont give anyone else a chance. we havent even started to talk about what a shareholder makes, when generally shareholders do nothing for the company in terms of productivity.   Singapore repeatedly does this thing where they penalise the poor and make jt easy for the rich. i'd use the COE system as another example:  Those foreign family office rich families that come in are paying no tax on their capital gains and dividend distributions when they come to singapore. They obviously feel pretty good, with 1-2million in tax savings per year compared to if they were in the US or the UK. where does the money go into? Maybe those luxury cars we see on the road? They certainly wouldnt mind it that much if we raised the COE prices for them would they? eg. Just look at the taxes you pay on a Maserati (luxury car) compared to a Toyota (basic car). The flat COE price is 100k. The other taxes for the toyota is likely to be around 35k given current tax structure (i will spare the details). Comparatively, a person who buys the Maserati,  is paying about 120k in taxes. Again, bearing in mind the rich already save up 30-50% in capital gains and dividends taxes, how much does this flat 95k increase in taxes to buy a luxury car hurt them? NOTHING.  But the 100k for the COE prices out even those basic cars and people who actually need them. Give those in need this basic commodity and suddenly people will realise that they do not need to live that close to the MRT or a bus stop, which makes your road planning and the issue with uneven distribution across houses with different locations much easier to solve. Having a kid becomes much easier. People will be much happier.  There are so many ways to go about doing this: 1. Limit number of cars per person 2. Offer COE rebates to households with kids or elderly when they only have one car per family. 3. adjust the tax system i mentioned earlier to tax those Maseratis much much more so that those rich families cant stock up on 5 cars and jack up the COE. You might be able to get even more of a tax revenue from this. 4. Tax the purchase of a 2nd car much MUCH more. no matter what job you do, no one individual needs to drive 2 cars at the same time. if you are rich and you want to, you can, but you should get taxed much more.  Less rich people bidding = lower COE prices. Simple.  Sure, you might have more cars on the road during those peak hours, but solving the income inequality problem should be more of a priority, because the current system basically only continues to incentivise the rich and negate the poor.  solve the main problem: distribution of wealth, force the wealthy to share, and we all get a much happier society, with more people employed and a better worklife balance.

commentText: I am a young senior and have experienced a sudden loss of a job 3 times (not my own doing).  Both Lena and Uzen look professional, sound great, but are facing numerous difficulties in landing a job - it is hard to explain.  One thing I noticed is that the speed of change in the hiring scene has been so fast with the use of automation and AI assisting in hiring tasks (such as reviewing and analyzing cover letters and resumes to design specific interview questions & batteries of tests for suitability).  Looking for a job has changed much from what I am familiar with.  What remains unchanged is the need to showcase your strengths when opportunities arise and impress your interviewer with your EQ & IQ.  In the meantime, while they wait for that job, it is a great time to explore other options that can help pay the bills.  Who knows, these short gigs can open new opportunities for them and bring them more job opportunities!  I wish them all the best in this brutal employment space :)

commentText: I‚Äôve just been laid off after decades of service, labelled as ‚Äúrole redundancy‚Äù after outsourcing. The irony? I wasn‚Äôt doing the outsourced tasks, I supervised and led the team. Logically, a seasoned supervisor should oversee the outsourced work, while the doers‚Äô roles would be redundant. Instead, younger, cheaper staff were elevated into supervisory roles, despite limited experience.  The official narrative? Restructuring and right-sizing. The hard truth? Long-serving, higher-paid, older employees are often first on the list. Age and loyalty become liabilities, though no company will admit it.  With Singapore‚Äôs retirement age rising, this quiet form of age discrimination will only intensify, unless we call it what it is.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I've come to the conclusion that I no longer want to chase after a language or framework. This changes all the time. I've also decided that I will no longer subject myself to being treated like a commodity at a cattle auction. In the end, all of this is designed to make you accept doing more for less. I think at some point we give in and accept unrealistic things because the "market demands it," or the influencer you follow or the group of followers in the bubble you're in dictates that this is the culture, technology, or method to be adopted. Yes, I went through a financial setback and had to accept working in other segments. But that didn't kill my desire to work with software. Today, I think the path is to work as an entrepreneur and consultant for small businesses, creating solutions for the region you live in or where you can work without creating a burden on your life. Another mistake I see is the industrialization of the IT workforce. We didn't start that way; we started in a garage or on a small project; we're not cattle.

Your job was mysterious and magical and few others were in the industry competing for these enchanted positions. I retired a few years ago.  Nowadays, computer techs are a commodity and the perception is of an office worker. You are disposable and can be replaced in days from thousands of other candidates in your field. You‚Äôre no more important than a file clerk.  I worked through the tech industry‚Äôs best years and retired (age 60) at the tail end of that time.  Best of luck but it‚Äôs going to be a crap shoot and the jobs are pretty harsh.

commentText: I'm sorry the market is so brutal.  I would suggest, in the meantime, code your own apps for sale in the app store.  Doing this will achieve a few powerful things: (1) keep your skills fresh, (2) create something to show off, (3) potentially make some good money on the sale of your apps, and (4) keep your mind sharp, fresh.  You can also use this time to achieve certifications.  At the end of the day, give major consideration in the idea of working for yourself, building your own solutions.

In short, the comapies are not necessarily looking at devs abroad for reducing cost, but take advantage to do what they think is the correct without the worries of problems or complains.

commentText: There is no such thing as a dream job unless you are self employed in your home town with good income, surrounded by your grannies and nannies and eating home food every day sitting on the lap of your mother! Every job is a challenge and a compromise and the further you get out from your comfort home or country the more challenging it gets. That is where Indian youths who have been pampered at home fail abroad with social adjustment in a new society. They are home sick all the time. They should be concentrating on learning new language, new culture, new skills, seeing new places, experiencing the diversity and nature and even enjoying the quietness and lonliness filled with personal advancement. Glad that you pointed out many of these things here. Europe or any where else is definitely not a bed of roses. Nobody is waiting for you with open arms to give you a job, a home or a car. It is a healthy struggle here all the way minus nepotism, corruption, unequality and injustice which you are hopefully trying to get away from.

videoDescription: New data shows Gen Z are plagued by employment pessimism. BBC Special Correspondent Katty Kay and LinkedIn's Aneesh ...
commentText: It is so exhausting this never-ending self-improvement. We have to study further and further and further but, we still can't afford the bare minimum, we're stressed and depressed. It's so overwhelming.

videoTitle: Young people can't find jobs. What should they do? | BBC Global
videoDescription: New data shows Gen Z are plagued by employment pessimism. BBC Special Correspondent Katty Kay and LinkedIn's Aneesh ...
commentText: I think it sucks that, when we were growing up, those of us who were from poor and uneducated families were promised that, if we studied, if we worked hard to have lots of education background, we could achieve what most had: a stable income and job, a home and a family. Now, whether you have that background or not, we are no longer able to get basic things to live. Now, it's never-ending studying or never-ending begging for a chance to be something we might not even like to be. We are honestly done. And tired.

commentText: Most of the issue stems from companies not hiring, and that's a global issue. You can't be hired for a job that doesn't exist. There will be positions posted but that doesn't mean the company is hiring. Even if they interview you, that doesn't mean they're hiring. On the contrary, they're more likely NOT hiring, period. No self-improvement, skills, or anything can get you a job if the company has no budget allocated for new hires. The problem is not the applicant.

SMH

commentText: I‚Äôm a dev and I have been writing code with AI since GPT 2. It‚Äôs great as a copilot but the moment you ‚Äúvibe it‚Äù and let it loose, the cracks are almost immediate. Even refactoring existing repos is problematic. The joke is, you get AI to code it. Only AI understands it and if it breaks (and it does every time) the debug takes forever. Consider this. I lay off 3 devs and get AI to code based on the backlog. I still need a human to review the pull request. And because nobody can really talk to the code, the blaming takes forever. I have to hire 3 devs just to check the code. I‚Äôd rather keep the 3 devs, give them AI tools and that makes them 10x right. That‚Äôs the reality now and I don‚Äôt see that changing. Also, man it‚Äôs making people with no concept of the implications or clean coding principles write a lot of slop.

Grads will eventually be required to start entering the work force at a higher rung, but by the time this happens a new cohort of fresh grads will have arrived who are even more AI native. commentText: This just feels like empty platitudes. I'm in a good position in my own work, but at 30 I look at what 22-23+ year olds are trying to sort through in the entry level market, and telling them they just need to "keep learning" and be "pro-you" doesn't pay their bills or help them land a job. They need opportunity, they clearly want it, and they're not getting it. Read however many books you want (I say, as a big reader myself), but when these young people are applying to hundreds of jobs with nary a response, that just doesn't cut it.  And while we're all navigating the changes AI brings "together" let's not be naive, there are people who are far better positioned to realize monetary gains from it should it be as transformative as is claimed, and it's not anyone earning five or even low-six figure salaries.

commentText: For inexperienced workers, I think another huge factor is the increasingly short-term way companies are run. It simply doesn't make sense to hire and train junior people when your company outlook is measured in quarters rather than decades, because they represent high risk of failure on critical short-term deadlines, compounded by high indirect cost to the productivity of the senior people that train them and could otherwise be focussed fully on critical tasks, both of which are naturally compounded by AI as an alternative, but existed well before it.  Add the pattern of company hopping that's more and more popular, which effectively means that training new people is paying for their next employer's benefit more than your own, and it's not hard to see why companies just don't want to deal with entry level people any more.  Of course, that's unsustainable in the long run, but for that, see both of the above: in a business where your incentives are quarterly and *you* expect to jump after a few years too, the long run is some future employee's problem, not yours.  Eventually I think we'll end up needing policy incentives for what I think of as "sustainable hiring" where there are subsidies or similar cost offsetting measures in place to encourage the creation of early career positions and training, because as senior people leave the workforce into retirement, there won't be enough young people gaining the experience to replace them, and that's not something companies are likely to fix for themselves in the current environment.

commentText: A big issue with the Unemployment Rate is that it is an artificially depressed number, as there are several criteria that get you removed from that rate, particularly those who have given up and are no longer looking despite not having a job. It also excludes those who are chronically Underemployed (<20h/week). the LISEP "True Rate of Unemployment" study insists that the actual rate of functional unemployment is closer to 25% than it is to the official figure of 4%.  Not that we'd know what the current rate of Unemployment is right now since we haven't gotten Jobs or GDP reports since October.

commentText: I think there is also another explanation why getting a job is more work then it used to be: It has become easier to reply to multiple jobs at the same time now online application is everywhere. This means that if you have 50 similar jobs with 50 interested people, in the past they would probably spread out between these jobs and every job only got a few replies. but now people just reply to pretty much all of these jobs. Which in the end means: a lot more work for everyone and a lot more applications on the same amount of jobs.   Not sure if there is any data on this since who and how many people respond to a job is generally information only insiders have, but I have definitely seen the amounts of responses to jobs we posted rise to absurd amounts.

commentText: When you eliminate jobs from a sector, the people from those jobs still need to survive, so they go to other sectors, this floods those other sectors and reduces jobs/person ratios, making getting those jobs more difficult. Either reduce job numbers or increase person numbers and the same effects occur.  Also, if no one is being hired into fields to learn the field, what happens when everyone skilled retires or dies? All of a sudden there is not a supply of experienced people anymore. If the bottom half of skilled labor is let off, left to let their skills wane and atrophy, what happens when the bottom half becomes the only half? (This of course assumes a significant correlation between time in field and skill in field)

commentText: The unemployment in Germany has risen to roughly 2,8 mio. people, yet that is still historically a quite low level. 1,6 mio. of these people have no degree / apprenticeship at all and 50% of unemployed have no German citizenship and might struggle with language, culture and education. Of the remaining 1,2 mio. people with degrees a third is 55+ with difficulties in acquiring new skills and a substantial number (I guess around 200k additionally) lives in so called lost regions of former industries both in the east and west. If you look at these numbers for Germany, the problem seems to be hiring freezes as the only ones that still hire are the state / government or any adjacent jobs to them. It doesn't look as bleak mid-term (roughly 400k more people retire from the workforce than young people entering it per year), yet that doesn't help in the short-term.   It is such a paradox situation, there is a lack of skilled workers and no one wants to hire the ones that are there due to the economic uncertainty and economic cooldown. Companies try to 'sit-it-out' till it gets better, a lot of my friends are overworked as companies put on more pressure instead of hiring new people. AI doesn't affect their jobs directly.   Guess everyone needs to skill up the next months to either prepare for a post-AI world (there will be jobs, yet the skills required are different) or go for another direction altogether (quite some people take double degrees now). The crazy thing is that multiple things happen all at once making it more difficult to find the right personal response to it.

commentText: >Unemployment is close to the historical average Using unemployment isn't entirely accurate, as you have to be actively looking for work to be unemployed; US 2014-2016 data are technically around average as Obama's "unemployment below 8%" claims, but a large part of that is a lot of unemployed workers stopped looking for work, and 2020-2023 caused a lot of people to retire early or just die because of COVID, so they don't technically count as unemployed and dead people don't count in labor force participation either. Underemployment due to people taking gig jobs or lower paying jobs can also misrepresent employment. Also, H-1B immigration necessarily requires having a job, so mass importing employed people from other countries during the Biden years will dilute the apparent unemployment rate among natives. It's a very imperfect metric.

commentText: It's not AI, it's low hiring/low firing economy, especially in the US. Companies are hoarding workers and not firing anyone, which keeps the unemployment rate low, but they're also not hiring any new people, which makes it hard to find a job. It's symptom of the weird permanently pre-recession economy the US is in where the economy is always on the brink of a recession but never goes under all the while headline numbers stay strong. Which is mostly a consequence of K shaped economy where headline numbers like GDP growth and consumption are propped up by the top 10% richest Americans who keep spending while everyone else cuts back.

commentText: 1:51 and 2:43‚Äî the official unemployment rate is almost constant in the US/UK/Germany, except COVID period. There's like 1.5x or less variation, that cannot be called "must harder to find a job". And the rest of the video is trying to explain why unemployment rate is rising (insignificantly), while in the beginning we saw that it's not rising (almost).  My one hypothesis for now is that while unemployment rate is constant, it may be still harder to change a job ‚Äî it may be less people taking more time to find a new job, so the total number time√ópeople is approximately constant. In case of IT it could be, for example, that companies consider much more candidates before choosing one due to some cultural shift after COVID, and that causes candidates to send much more resumes and spend much more time to find a new job (I mean AI resume filtering stage + more interviews for more candidates before hiring + more remote jobs to choose from a larger candidate pool). That's an assumption, I don't have hard data for this except for long term unemployment that grows faster than simple unemployment since early 2023. My second hypothesis is that the official unemployment statistics may not reflect the real unemployment for some reason.
